Note: Lowell Thomas and President Franklin D. Roosevelt shared the same stomping ground, the Mid-Hudson Valley. Mr. Thomas lived in Pawling, New York, and President Roosevelt, in Hyde Park, New York, some 20 miles away. Verso: Beginning of rivalry; Gonzalez Studio, 515 Madison Ave.

For use in publications: Tibet

Note: The Potala Palace, or "The Palace of the Gods," rises 900 feet above the Lhasa Plain. From street level, this is approximately two-thirds the height of the Empire State Building. The photograph was taken by Lowell Thomas, Jr. on his journey to Tibet with his father in 1949.
[Photograph of The Potala Palace]

A curious contrivance called a steel otter. L.T. and an officer in the royal Naval Reserve are having a look at this monster which was used in the Mediterranean by the British to sweep up mines. This picture was taken on board a British munitions ship that was making its way through the mine fields and submarine-infested waters of the Mediterranean. Verso: An otter on board British merchant vessel in Mediterranean. These otters were to sweep up mines

Note: A curious contrivance called a steel otter. L.T. and an officer in the royal Naval Reserve are having a look at this monster which was used in the Mediterranean by the British to sweep up mines. This picture was taken on board a British munitions ship that was making its way through the mine fields and submarine-infested waters of the Mediterranean. Verso: An otter on board British merchant vessel in Mediterranean. These otters were to sweep up mines

L.T. wearing army campaign hat, accompanied by two members of his staff, rowing down one of the canals of Venice, during the war when Venice was almost a deserted city. The Austrians and Germans were pounding away with their artillery just fourteen miles across the lagoons [Major Piero Tozzi on left, Theodore Roosevelt, Jr. on right]

Note: L.T. wearing army campaign hat, accompanied by two members of his staff, rowing down one of the canals of Venice, during the war when Venice was almost a deserted city. The Austrians and Germans were pounding away with their artillery just fourteen miles across the lagoons [Major Piero Tozzi on left, Theodore Roosevelt, Jr. on right]

L.T. and two of his colleagues, on a journey along the canals of Venice at a time when the City of Canals was almost deserted. The Austrians were banging away with their artillery just fourteen miles distant and nearly the entire population had fled [Major Piero Tozzi on left, Theodore Roosevelt, Jr. on right] [2 copies]

Note: L.T. and two of his colleagues, on a journey along the canals of Venice at a time when the City of Canals was almost deserted. For use in publications: Miscellaneous photographs

IN 25th RADIO YEAR Lowell Thomas, CBS Radio newscaster who has become a "friend of the family" to millions of American listeners, has just entered his 25th broadcasting year. Here the adventurous newsman, who has reported from far-flung exploring posts around the globe, does some research in his vast library for his current activities with the Monday-thru-Friday evening "Lowell Thomas and the News" and with his Cinerama project [circa 1954]

Note: IN 25th RADIO YEAR Lowell Thomas, CBS Radio newscaster who has become a "friend of the family" to millions of American listeners, has just entered his 25th broadcasting year. Here the adventurous newsman, who has reported from far-flung exploring posts around the globe, does some research in his vast library for his current activities with the Monday-thru-Friday evening "Lowell Thomas and the News" and with his Cinerama project [circa 1954]
